Name: Haloxyfop
Description: 2-(4-{[3-chloro-5-(trifluoromethyl)pyridin-2-yl]oxy}phenoxy)propanoic acid is a monocarboxylic acid that is 2-phenoxypropanoic acid in which the hydrogen at the para position of the phenyl ring has been replaced by a [3-chloro-5-(trifluoromethyl)pyridin-2-yl]oxy group. It is a member of pyridines, an aromatic ether, a monocarboxylic acid, an organofluorine compound and an organochlorine compound.

plant_translocations.content: Laboratory experiments with 14C-herbicides were conducted with grain sorghum as an indicator species to determine the effects of imposed moisture stress on absorption, precent recovery, and acropetal and basipetal translocation of the butyl ester of fluazifop, the methyl ester of haloxyfop, the ethyl ester of quizalofop, and sethoxydim. Haloxyfop was the only herbicide where recovery decreased between the 3-and 48-h interval. All plants absorbed more of the herbicide at the 48-h interval than at the 3- or 6-h interval under both stressed and non-stressed conditions. Increased drought stress caused more acropetal movement with fluazifop and sethoxydim and less acropetal movement with quizalofop at the 3-h interval. Basipetal transloation, although different among herbicides, responded similarly to imposed moisture stress, which decreased basipetal translocation approximately 19%.
plant_translocations.reference: Reynolds, D. B., Wheless, T. G., Basler, E., & Murray, D. S. (1988). Moisture stress effects on absorption and translocation of four foliar-applied herbicides. Weed Technology, 2(4), 437-441.

method.Plant Grown Condition: The plants were grown in a controlled environment chamber with a temperature regime of 29°C days and 21°C nights, a daytime relative humidity of 80% (±5%), and a 12-h photoperiod at an average photosynthetic photon flux density of 240 μE·m−2·s−1.
method.Chemical Preparation: Herbicides fluazifop (0.05 μCi/μl, carboxyl-14C), quizalofop (0.05 μCi/μl, phenol-14C), haloxyfop (0.05 μCi/μl, phenoxy-UL-14C), and sethoxydim (0.05 μCi/μl, H4-14C) were dissolved in acetone with 0.47% (v/v) octoxynol added.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Two drops of the respective 14C-herbicide solution were applied to the second most fully expanded true leaf 3 cm above the leaf collar.
method.Other Information: The experimental design was a randomized complete block with a 3x2x4 factorial treatment arrangement and four replications

plant_translocations.result: [{"Moisture stress": "High", "Hours after application": 3, "Translocated acropetally from treated area (%)": 7}, {"Moisture stress": "High", "Hours after application": 6, "Translocated acropetally from treated area (%)": 6}, {"Moisture stress": "High", "Hours after application": 48, "Translocated acropetally from treated area (%)": 11}, {"Moisture stress": "Low", "Hours after application": 3, "Translocated acropetally from treated area (%)": 19}, {"Moisture stress": "Low", "Hours after application": 6, "Translocated acropetally from treated area (%)": 6}, {"Moisture stress": "Low", "Hours after application": 48, "Translocated acropetally from treated area (%)": 10}]

plant_translocations.content: Glasshouse studies evaluated the impact of moisture stress on the phytotoxicity of haloxyfop and its absorption, translocation, and metabolism in johnsongrass and large crabgrass. Haloxyfop applied at 30 g ai ha^-1 to crabgrass and 25 g ai ha^-1 to johnsongrass showed 92% control in non-stressed plants but less than 12% in water-stressed plants after 15 days. Moisture stress reduced 14C-haloxyfop absorption and translocation at various intervals post-treatment but did not affect its metabolism. Moisture stress also decreased 14C-photoassimilate fixation and distribution, mirroring the reductions in 14C-haloxyfop translocation, thereby reducing haloxyfop's phytotoxicity in both grasses.
plant_translocations.reference: Peregoy, R. S., Kitchen, L. M., Jordan, P. W., & Griffin, J. L. (1990). Moisture stress effects on the absorption, translocation, and metabolism of haloxyfop in johnsongrass (Sorghum halepense) and large crabgrass (Digitaria sanguinalis). Weed Science, 38(4-5), 331-337.

method.Test Plant: Johnsongrass (Sorghum halepense) and Large Crabgrass (Digitaria sanguinalis)
method.Plant Grown Condition: The plants were grown in 1-L plastic containers filled with a peat-based potting mixture in a glasshouse. The glasshouse was covered with two layers of shadecloth blocking over 90% of natural sunlight, and a 14-h photoperiod was maintained using metal halide lamps providing approximately 500 μE/m2/s of photosynthetically active radiation.
method.Chemical Preparation: A radiolabeled haloxyfop stock solution was prepared with uniformly phenyl-ring-labeled 14C-haloxyfop-methyl (6.16 x 108 Bq/mmol) dissolved in acetone. The treatment solution contained 14C-haloxyfop, 5% (v/v) acetone, 0.04% (v/v) commercially formulated haloxyfop, and 1% (v/v) petroleum oil concentrate (POC).
method.Other Information: The plants were harvested at 1, 3, 5, 24, 48, 72, and 96 hours after treatment (HAT).
